questions.question_text: Which virtual warehouse privilege is required to view a load-monitoring chart?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
To view the load monitoring chart, you must be using a role that has the MONITOR privilege on the warehouse.

Selected Answer: A
A. MONTTOR

Selected Answer: C
“Exploding” joins

One of the common mistakes SQL users make is joining tables without providing a join condition (resulting in a “Cartesian product”), or providing a condition where records from one table match multiple records from another table. For such queries, the Join operator produces significantly (often by orders of magnitude) more tuples than it consumes.

Selected Answer: C
C. A query that has not specified join criteria for tables

C Correct, It's also called cartesian product

questions.question_text: Which use case will always cause an exploding join in Snowflake?

choices.B: A query that is using a UNION without an ALL.
choices.A: A query that has more than 10 left outer joins.
choices.C: A query that has not specified join criteria for tables.
choices.D: A query that has requested too many columns of data.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
A resource monitor can track multiple warehouses, but each warehouse can be linked to only one resource monitor.

Selected Answer: B
Note, however, that a warehouse can be assigned to only a single resource monitor below the account level.

A resource monitor can be set to monitor multiple warehouses but a warehouse can be assigned only to a single resource monitor.

questions.question_text: How many resource monitors can be applied to a single virtual warehouse?

choices.D: Data retention for account usage views is 1 year but is 7 days to 6 months for information schema views, depending on the view.
choices.E: Information schema views are read-only but account usage views are not.
choices.B: Account usage views do not contain data about tables but information schema views do.
choices.A: No active warehouse is needed to query account usage views but one is needed to query information schema views.
choices.C: Account usage views contain dropped objects but information schema views do not.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
C&D
Certain account usage views provide historical usage metrics. The retention period for these views is 1 year (365 days). In contrast, the corresponding views and table functions in the Snowflake Information Schema have much shorter retention periods, ranging from 7 days to 6 months, depending on the view.

Selected Answer: CD
CD are correct
This question is in My Exam

I would say C and D

questions.question_text: What are the main differences between the account usage views and the information schema views? (Choose two.)
True or False: Bulk unloading of data from Snowflake supports the use of a SELECT statement.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A - True

Selected Answer: A
A.true

Selected Answer: A
Unloading allows to store data in multiple files. It also allows to join which is not allowed in loading.
A.True

Selected Answer: A
A. true
True A

the best answer is : A 

Snowflake supports specifying a SELECT statement instead of a table in the COPY INTO <location> command. The results of the query are written to one or more files as specified in the command and the file(s) are stored in the specified location (internal or external).
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/data-unload-overview#bulk-unloading-using-queries

Bullk unload supports "SELECT" statements and the answer is True. See query below

COPY INTO @my_stage/my_unloaded_data.csv
FROM (
 SELECT col1, col2, col3
 FROM my_table
 WHERE condition
)
FILE_FORMAT = (FORMAT_NAME = 'CSV' COMPRESSION = 'AUTO');

False
Unload into file_name
from my_table
File_format = CSV

B
UNLOAD INTO @stage_name/files
FROM my_table
FILE_FORMAT = (TYPE = 'CSV');

Selected Answer: A
A is correct
It's a little bit confuse due to BULK keyword, but the correct answer is A.

A is correct

A is correct

Snowflake supports specifying a SELECT statement instead of a table in the COPY INTO <location> command
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/data-unload-overview.html
Answer is A, supports select
Ans is A

Per Snowflakes documentation linked bulk unloading supports select:

"Snowflake supports specifying a SELECT statement instead of a table in the COPY INTO <location> command. The results of the query are written to one or more files as specified in the command and the file(s) are stored in the specified location (internal or external)."

comments.content:
Agreed. Snowflake supports select statement in COPY INTO command.
